heading.title: PRINTING AND KINDRED INDUSTRIES UNION OF AUSTRALIA v CLARK

case:info.case:casename: PRINTING AND KINDRED INDUSTRIES UNION OF AUSTRALIA v CLARK

catchwords.catchphrase: Separate decision of questions in proceedings

p.text: The application of the plaintiff is that the issue raised by para 4(b) of the defence be decided separately from any other question before the trial. Part 31 r 2 gives the court a discretion to make such an order. It is, of course, a discretion to be exercised in a judicial manner and in accordance with accepted principles. The plaintiff says that the substance of the defence is contained in para 4(b) and that if it is decided that that paragraph constitutes no defence to the proceedings the hearing of the case would be substantially shortened. If it were to be decided that it were a valid defence the proceedings would not be shortened but would probably, taking into account the hearing of this application and the hearing of the substance of the motion, be somewhat extended. For the purposes of this application the plaintiff is prepared to concede that the assertion of fact in para 4(b) is probably accurate, but there is no suggestion that there would, on the hearing of the proceedings, be any such admission. In Carl Zeiss Stiftung v Herbert Smith & Co [1969] 1 Ch 93 at 98 , Lord Denning MR said: “I know that it has been said on one or two occasions that a preliminary issue should be ordered only when, whichever way it is decided, it is conclusive of the whole matter. That was said by Lord Evershed MR in Windsor Refrigerator Co Ltd v Branch Nominees Ltd [1961] Ch 375; [1961] 1 All ER 277 ; and Harman LJ in Yeoman Credit Ltd v Latter [1961] 1 WLR 828 . I do not think that is correct.

“The true rule was stated by Romer LJ in Everett v Ribbands [1952] 2 QB 198; [1952] 1 All ER 823 ‘Where you have a point of law which, if decided in one way, is going to be decisive of litigation, then advantage ought to be taken of the facilities afforded by the Rules of the court to have it disposed of at the close of proceedings, or very shortly after the close of proceedings.’

“I have always understood such to be the practice. I quite agree that in many cases the facts and law are so mixed up that it is very undesirable to have a preliminary issue. I always like to know the facts before deciding the law. But this is an exceptional case. The solicitors have received in good faith moneys for the defence of this action. They ought to know at once whether they can safely go on receiving them. If the issue of law is decided in their favour, it will dispose of the claim against them, irrespective of the main action. I would order a preliminary issue to be tried.”

The plaintiff relied upon this statement of principle, but when faced with the contention that in the present case the principle expounded by Romer LJ was not apt because there were two other grounds of defence set out in para 4 of the defence, submitted that neither of those defences could be considered on this application because that contained in para 4(a) was plainly indefensible and that contained in para 4(c) inconsistent with the allegations in para 4(b).

I think the proper principle is that taken by Lord Denning MR from the judgment of Romer LJ. I do not think on an application such as this that I can assess the worth of other defences raised by the defendant. If the plaintiff takes the view that the defence in para 4(b) is the only defence to its statement of claim, it has available to it the remedy of application to strike out the other defences — cf Radstock Co-op and Industrial Society Ltd v Norton-Radstock Urban District Council [1968] Ch 605 at 624; [1968] 2 All ER 59 per Harman LJ. I cannot, as I have said, in an application under Pt 31 r 2, assess the validity of defences other than the one the subject of the application.

It follows, in my opinion, that whatever conclusion might be reached as to the validity as a defence of para 4(b) in each of the defences, these proceedings would not be finally determined. It would follow, in my opinion, that I should not exercise the power given to the court by Pt 31 r 2, and I therefore dismiss the motion.
